column76: Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

column75: A depiction of "an instrument which will shew at any houre of the night, how much the Loadstar is either above or beneath the Pole." This illustration is particularly interesting because a former owner made the instrument by stitching a paper disc and a paper needle to the page.
column121: Page 720, illustration from 'The Art of Navigation', entitled, 'The Shape or Figure of the Rectifier of the North Starre'

column75: A catalogue of the highway distances between cities in England.
column121: Discription of the High-ways in England and Wales; Page spread, folios C3-C4

column75: An illustration of a mariner's quadrant, a device used to determine one's latitude at sea
An illustration of a mine ventilation system. The vane (H) orients the wooden vessel (A) so that the vent (C) faces the wind. The wind forces fresh air through a pipe (D) and into the mine.

column76: Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

column75: Illustration of nested regular solids, depicting Kepler's model of the solar system. Saturn's orbit circumscribes the cube, Jupiter's orbit the tetrahedron, Mars' orbit the dodecahedron, Earth's orbit the icosahedron, and Venus' orbit the octahedron. Mercury's orbit is nested inside the octahedron.

A table illustrating the influence of the planets and the zodiac on maladies in specific parts of the body. The signs of the planets are listed in the first row, and the signs of the zodiac run down the first column.
Contains Philip Staynred's 'A Compendium of Fortification.'
column76: Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University
column109: Anne Godbid for William Fisher, Edward Thomas, Robert Boulter, Thomas Passinger, Ralph Smith, and Richard Northcot.

column75: A mathematical ruler. The ruler is inserted at the beginning of the first book.
An advertisement for Robert Hartwell's teaching services.
column121: First page of treatise entitled, 'Arts and Sciences Mathematicall'

column75: An opening of A Prognostication for euer. The page on the left provides a rule  for determining the beginning and endings of the Hilary, Easter, Trinity, and Michaelmas terms. The page on the right provides a table for determining "how long the Moon shineth, and when she riseth and setteth."

column76: Avery Architectural and Fine Arts Library, Columbia University
column121: Opera Nuova di Fortificare, Offendere, et Diffendere

column75: An illustration of a fortification and soldiers.
Cherubim experimenting with magnetic globes.

The cherubim in the top illustration experiment with magnets and metal objects, such as keys and rings. The cherubim in the bottom illustration experiment with magnets and knives. The two angels in the middle magnetize the knives they are holding, while the two angels on the outside use magnetized knives to attract nails.
1694 edition of almanac
column76: Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University
column109: Thomas Basset, Richard Chiswel, Samuel Smith, Benjamin Walford, and George Conyers
column121: Prognostication for Ever, Made by Erra Pater, a Jew, born in Jewry, Doctor in Astronomy and Physick: Very Profitable to keep the Body in health. And also Ptolomeus saith the same. Together with the Fairs and High-Ways, and several new Additions

column75: Formulae for bills and obligations.
Figure 1 in Elevation des eaux par toute sorte de machines depicts hoses used in an experiment to determine the weight of the River Seine.
A cross-sectional illustration of a mine. A turbine powers three subterranean piston pumps in succession to drain a flooded mine shaft.
A fold-out illustration depicting astronomical instruments.
A table designed to help the reader calculate 6% interest on any sum of money from 1 shilling to 1 pound, from a day to a year.
An illustration depicting the heliocentric universe.
column121: Page 112, illustration entitled, 'Narratio, Ordo Sphaerarum Mundi'

column75: A cross-section of a fort.
column121: Unnumbered page, detail, from Philip Staynred's 'A Compendium of Fortification.'

column75: Kepler describes the alignment of the platonic solids in the solar system. The four illustrations depict flattened views from within the octahedron looking out. The horizontal line is the square bisecting the octahedron, and the other lines show the edges of the remaining solids. The third illustration from the top depicts an alignment in which the angles of the solids are aligned, an alignment which Kepler rejects. The fourth illustration depicts the alignment of the solids in Kepler's model.
A cross-section of Mount Vesuvius, depicting the inside of the crater, which Kircher explored in 1638.

An illustration of the human arm holding a weight. The illustration includes the arm's range of motion. Above and below the arm are two Bible verses in Hebrew, with Psalm 139:14-15 below and Job 10:2 above.
A cross-sectional illustration of a mine. Gears and drive-shafts harness horse power to operate an underground ore lift.

column121: Catalogue of the fairs in England and Wales; Unnumbered page, recto

column75: A blank astrological chart. Each of the twelve triangles corresponds to one of the signs of the zodiac.
"A Scale of Fortification," a mathematical ruler used in the construction of forts.

column75: An anatomy, illustrating blood vessels in the feet, left hand, and right arm.
An illustration of the planets' epicycles.
A dialling scale.

column75: An illustration of the surface of the sun.
